sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Hello, you're watching Euronews tonight, our top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Austria becomes the first EU country to make COVID-19 vaccines mandatory as it reintroduces a national lockdown from Monday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Migrant camps on the Belarus border with Poland have now been cleared, but illegal attempts to enter the bloc continue.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Brussels says its relationship with the UK is intrinsically tied but deeply divided as more talks take place over the disputed Northern Ireland Protocol.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Also in Talking Culture, 19, 21, 25 and now 30. Adele's new album is out and the cast of Harry Potter is coming back for a reunion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Good evening and welcome to the programme. I'm Takumbo Salako.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Austrians will be going back into a full national lockdown from Monday as the government decides to make COVID-19 vaccinations mandatory from February. It follows a surge in coronavirus cases. More than 15,000 were reported in the last 24 hours. Austria's vaccination uptake is one of the lowest in Western Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Non-essential shops will close, people will have to work from home and some schools will shut.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Next week's measures will be reassessed after 10 days but look set to last at least double that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Chancellor Alexander Schellenberg says it's the only way to contain the health emergency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Chancellor Alexander Schallenberg says it's the only way to contain the health emergency.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: For a long time, the political consensus was that we don't want a vaccine mandate in this country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But we have to look reality in the eye.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: For a long time, maybe too long, me and others thought that it must be possible to convince people in Austria to convince them to get vaccinated voluntarily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: to convince people in Austria to convince them to get vaccinated voluntarily.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Increasing the vaccination rate, and I think we're all in agreement on this, is our only way to break out of this vicious cycle of vile waves and lockdown discussions for good.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: We don't want a fifth wave, we don't want a sixth and seventh wave.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Johannes Plaschberger says a huge anti-vaccination protest is planned against these new restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: This makes Austria, next to the Vatican, the first country in Europe to impose such a measure.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Obviously, there has been an outstir among anti-vaccine protesters such as the Austrian People's, Austrian Freedom Party, which has announced a major demonstration in Vienna's city center tomorrow, Saturday, with supposedly more than 10,000 people attending.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, the Austrian Medical Association has praised the government for taking these measures, not just mandatory vaccination, but also the lockdown for everyone which will come into effect this Monday. Because according to these medical experts there was no other measure available to fight the rising new infections. Because daily there have been record highs of new infections in Austria and the situation in hospitals especially in the Salzburg and upper Austria regions, remains critical. Johannes Blechberger, Milchstätter See in Carinthia region, Austria for Euronews. Across the border from Austria in Bavaria,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: all Christmas markets have now been cancelled because of the surge in coronavirus infections.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A full lockdown will also be implemented in areas where the COVID-19 incident rate is over 1,000 per 100,000 people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Currently, it will affect at least eight districts. Clubs, bars and all restaurants will also be shut for three weeks in the southern German state, but schools will remain open.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But across Bavaria, a de facto lockdown for unvaccinated people will begin. State Premier Marcus Söder is calling for mandatory vaccinations. Alongside the low vaccination rate, and let's be honest here, carelessness and the lack of solidarity are the main reasons. For a long time, we've taken care of the unvaccinated. Now we have to take less care of those who do not care at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: This is not fun. It's one of the hardest things to decide, but it's necessary.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: What drives us and moves us is a concern for the life of the people and our state, Bavaria.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Over in Hungary, wearing masks indoors and in enclosed spaces will become mandatory from Saturday. It would also be compulsory for health care staff to receive a booster jab. More than 11,000 new coronavirus cases have been recorded in the last day, the highest level of infections so far in the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Authorities say the fourth wave could peak later this month or early December.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: For a third day in a row, Russia has reported a record number of coronavirus deaths. More than 1,250 people died in the last 24 hours as infections continue to rise. In total, more than 260,000 people have died, the highest number in Europe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's despite the number of cases falling.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Belarusian authorities say they've cleared the migrant camps along its border with Poland, but Warsaw says Minsk is still bringing people to the frontier. The people are now being housed in warehouse facilities near the border that follows the first repatriation flight taking off for Iraq. But Polish border guards say people are still trying to cross the frontier. They say in the last 24 hours there have been at least 250 attempts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Our reporter Mary Goriat is at the border and says Polish officials see a different

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: side of the story to Belarus. The decision by Belarus to move the migrants from their makeshift camps at the border to a warehouse nearby was largely seen as an effort to de-escalate the standoff between Minsk and the European Union, the perception here on the Polish side of the border in the Kusznica area is very different. For one thing, Polish authorities are still accusing Belarusian forces of inducing migrants to cross the border. Security forces in the area are saying that they've prevented attempts from hundreds of people to storm the fence this week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Another cause for concern are the reports coming from the Belarus border from journalists and migrants, according to which groups of people are being boarded on buses to be taken to unknown destinations.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The presumption and the speculation is that they are being taken to other parts of the border away from the epicenter of the crisis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Now there are signs that could corroborate that.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Polish activists who've been rescuing migrants for weeks in the Kusznica area say they've hardly had any activity in the past few days.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: On the other hand, groups of activists did carry out a number of rescues at the south of the border where groups of migrants are getting through.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So from here, it doesn't look like the situation is likely to improve soon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: From here, it doesn't look like the situation is likely to improve soon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And the Polish government did not take well to the talks this week between German Chancellor Angela Merkel and Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Warsaw does not believe intends, at least not hastily, to de-escalate the crisis, which many here still believe could become explosive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Valery Gorya from Eastern Poland for Euronews. Let's get a little bit more now on the situation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We can talk to Hanna Lubecovo.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: She's a journalist and non-resident fellow at the Atlantic Council.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, thanks for taking time to speak to us here on the program.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Can we see all of this as an attempt by Belarus to de-escalate the situation?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, at least that's something that Lukashenko is trying to show. all of this as an attempt by Belarus to de-escalate the situation?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, at least that's something that Lukashenko is trying to show. Merkel, Angela Merkel, has called him twice since the beginning of the week and the first flight to Iraq already took place yesterday. 400 migrants were evacuated but it does not mean that all of the migrants are going back to their countries. Thousands, again, thousands of people are in Belarus and it's a good question, it's a big question of what is going to happen with them because they rough sleep on the streets, they don't have where to go. On the border, people were taken to warehouse, to this large logistical centre where packages are being normally held. And that's where they they're being accommodated right now. However most recently a Covid case was discovered there was reported there. So it also means that they are in a dangerous situation there. So the crisis is not might also be happening Covid wise on the border. And there are still people who THE BORDER.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: THERE IS A LOT OF CONVERSATION THERE, SO THE CRISIS MIGHT ALSO BE HAPPENING COVID-WISE ON THE BORDER.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: THERE ARE STILL PEOPLE WHO ARE ATTEMPTING TO CROSS IT.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: YESTERDAY, POLAND SAID THAT DESPITE HELPING MIGRANTS TO GET THEM TO THIS WAREHOUSE AND CLEARING THE CAMP, AGAIN, ATTEMPTS, HUNDREDS OF ATTEMPTS TO CROSS THE BORDER TOOK PLACE, border took place. So it only means that the crisis continues. Let's talk a bit more about those that outbreak of a COVID in that warehouse. We any idea how authorities plan to respond to this. It's actually quite a cynical situation I would say because Nationwide, Lukashenko actually banned masks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So he at some point said that we have to resign from this mask regime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So it was introduced, but then the whole country had to sort of get used to the situation when they don't have to wear masks anymore.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But then at some point on the border, the Red Cross and other border guards, other organizations were offering migrants masks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And there was even this information that they might be vaccinated at some point.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: And the level of vaccination in Belarus is very low because people don't trust this Russian Sputnik vaccine or the Chinese vaccine.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So the situation is very interesting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: the Chinese vaccine. So the situation is very interesting. At some point, on one hand, the regime in Belarus is ignoring the crisis, the COVID pandemic. On the other hand, they're trying to show that they're helping migrants with this by bringing masks. So it all looks very cynical. It all does not seem as if the regime in Belarus is looking for a real solution.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And how is all of this being reflected or reported in the media?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Are people generally aware of what's going on, what's being said on both sides of the border?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Of course.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Well, when people in Belarus see thousands of migrants on the streets and in Minsk, because they are in cities as well, and they see what's happening on the border, they have many questions. Firstly, how these migrants were brought to Belarus and there were investigations. There was evidence that these state owned tourism agencies were involved in issuing visas in selling tourism packages to migrants from the Middle East. So people blame, accuse the regime of making Belarus the illegal, the hub for irregular migration. At the same time, propaganda is actually saying that, oh, since Ando Merkel called Lukashenko twice, then Lukashenko has become legitimate. He's been recognized worldwide, and everybody is happy to talk to him again. But it does not mean so. It means only that Germany and the EU wants to resolve the crisis on the border. And Lukashenko is also scared of sanctions when sanctions on Belavia the state airline monopolist company in Belarus were announced, actually, Belavia said that they would not bring migrants on board from the Middle East, from several countries, including Syria and Iraq.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: So people also see this.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: People see the reactions, the responses of the authorities, of the regime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And they, despite the media blackout in in Belarus they actually know who is behind the crisis. Hanna Lubakova journalist and non-resident fellow at the Atlantic Council thank you for sharing your thoughts with us here on Euronews tonight. The EU and the UK remain far apart on

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: the issues surrounding the Northern Ireland protocol that follows the latest round of talks in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Ahead of the meeting between the two sides, Commission Vice President Mara Sefcovic stressed that serious headway needed to be made.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: But the Brexit Minister, David Frost, mooted the possibility of any major breakthroughs happening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, let's go over to Brussels now where we can speak to our correspondent there, Shona Murray, for more on those talks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Shona, threats and counter threats were made before this meeting regarding the triggering of Article 16.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Is the so-called nude music sort of reaching a crescendo or is it diminishing down?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I think that the tone is much more lighter. I think there's a much more of a conciliatory approach relatively speaking, Toast, compared to what you said there earlier the last few weeks and months we've been talking about the nuclear option, the UK triggering article 16, suspending or ending all checks on goods coming from Great Britain to Northern Ireland, the implications of that being a massive trade war. So the language today is that there has been some momentum on talks but but as you said, there are significant gaps remain. Sides are far apart. We've heard this language before throughout the Brexit debate. And there's significant gaps when it comes to what those checks should look like, if any, on goods going from Great Britain to Northern Ireland, discussions around medicines and some of the essentially implications of the protocol itself.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Those issues really need to be worked out.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And, of course, as we know, for the UK, the removal of the European Court of Justice as an arbiter of the Northern Ireland protocol, something that the EU says it won't countenance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Shona, we're a bit like detectives pouring over clues now, because, you know, Maros Seskovic said before the talk that neither side could live without the others. We are a bit like detectives pouring over clues now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Maros says neither side could live without the other.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Is that a sign the EU could be willing to compromise?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The EU's position is that it has already compromised.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It set out a list of far-reaching proposals that were designed to deal with the practical implications of the protocol. So from its position, it already has compromised and that the EUK, what it needs to do is reciprocate on those compromises. So Brussels' position is it's gone far enough. In fact, when you talk to member states and diplomats, when they decided to make these sort of derogations of the UK you know some countries were saying they're gone too far so Brussels position is very much that the eat the UK needs now does it reciprocate Jonah Murray there on those talks which still gone ongoing set to continue next week that's reporting for us in Brussels thank you now it's been a

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: six-year wait for her fans, but it's finally over as Adele returns with her new album, 30, which is released today.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: If the reaction to last month's single, Easy On Me, which went to number one in 25 countries, is anything to go by, then this collection won't see her fall off her mantle as the queen of heartbreak.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So is it a winning formula?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, let's bring in Andrea Belytho to find out.

sentences.sentence: Andrea, have you heard it, Adele's new album?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's very, very personal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It's about her break-up, the breakdown of her relationship with the father of her child. It's about her break up, the breakdown of her relationship with the father of her child. It's about her divorce, it's about coming to terms with being a single mum to her young son. It's perhaps not quite as black and white as some of her earlier work like Hello and Someone Like You. It's a bit messier and more uncertain and questioning but she sticks with the winning formula.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Our superheroes on screen have proved to be less heroic when it comes to being green.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In Hungary, though, one organisation is trying to reduce the amount of plastic used on film sets, and it started with the Marvel franchise. Thomas Bolton has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Have you ever considered what a film costs to make?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Not economically, but environmentally.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Here in Hungary, the Marvel franchise recently produced their new series and 25 tons of waste along with it. But local production team Green Eyes championed green filmmaking and aimed to save the world from climate disaster. The films generate much more food waste because of the COVID as everything has to be packed and ordered a week in advance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Unfortunately, they use 10 boxes per person every day.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The crew made the change to biodegradable bowls and cups, which then decompose in these brown bins.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Any food wasted will only help the decomposition process, meaning that much of the leftovers produced by Marvel's filming was turned into biogas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: By composting biological waste we reduce the size of the landfills and the amount of methane gas that they release to the atmosphere.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: This compost was once plastic packaging used by superheroes on set.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The bio-waste was first ground down and then turned into topsoil where plants can grow.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The green-minded team collected more than two tons of paper, cardboard and plastic in their endeavor to cut harmful waste.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: The European Union hopes to meet its environmental targets by asking member states to encourage their citizens to compost at home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Well, that's it from me and the team on Euronews tonight.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We leave you with this no comment from Marseille in France and the grand final of the PWA Windsurf World Cup.
